hawaiian_text: ‘O Hō‘ae‘ae ma ‘Ewa ka ‘āina, ma laila lāua i  launa kino ai me ka moe ‘ana iho ā loa‘a ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o. A hāpai ‘o Pōka‘ī iā   Nāmakaokapāo‘o, ho‘i akula ‘o Kauluakaha‘i i kona  ‘āina, noho ihola ‘o Pōka‘ī me kona hāpai, a ma hope, hānau. Ma kēia hānau ‘ana, he ‘ilihune loa ‘o  Pōka‘ī a me kāna keiki ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o.
llama4-maverick-fireworks_translation: The land was Hō‘ae‘ae in ‘Ewa; it was there that the two came together physically and slept, and Nāmakaokapāo‘o was conceived. When Pōka‘ī became pregnant with Nāmakaokapāo‘o, Kauluakaha‘i returned to his land, and Pōka‘ī remained with her pregnancy, and later, she gave birth. During this time of giving birth, Pōka‘ī and her child, Nāmakaokapāo‘o, were extremely poor.
raw_response:
<translation>The land was Hō‘ae‘ae in ‘Ewa; it was there that the two came together physically and slept, and Nāmakaokapāo‘o was conceived. When Pōka‘ī became pregnant with Nāmakaokapāo‘o, Kauluakaha‘i returned to his land, and Pōka‘ī remained with her pregnancy, and later, she gave birth. During this time of giving birth, Pōka‘ī and her child, Nāmakaokapāo‘o, were extremely poor.</translation>

<commentary>**Paragraph 2:** 
• The paragraph continues the story of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o, focusing on the events surrounding his conception and birth; 
• The name Hō‘ae‘ae (to agree or to assent repeatedly) is associated with a place in ‘Ewa, indicating the location where Pō-ka-'ī and Ka-ulu-a-kaha'i had physical relations and conceived Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o. The toponym Hō‘ae‘ae may be interpreted as a place of agreement or acceptance, potentially signifying the mutual consent between the two individuals;
– The use of 'Ewa as the broader geographical context is significant, as 'Ewa is a region on O'ahu known for its historical and cultural importance;
• The phrase "ma laila lāua i launa kino ai me ka moe ‘ana iho" indicates a consensual and intimate encounter between Pō-ka-'ī and Ka-ulu-a-kaha'i, highlighting the cultural context of relationships and conception;
• After conceiving Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o, Ka-ulu-a-kaha'i returns to his land, leaving Pō-ka-'ī to carry the pregnancy to term and give birth. This abandonment or separation may symbolize the challenges faced by single parents or the changing dynamics of relationships in ancient Hawaiian society;
• The narrative highlights the extreme poverty ("he ‘ilihune loa") experienced by Pō-ka-'ī and her child, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o, during this period. The term ‘ilihune (extreme poverty) is noteworthy as it indicates a state of being very poor, destitute, or lacking the basic necessities. This could be an allegorical representation of the struggles faced by many during certain periods in Hawaiian history or a specific narrative device to illustrate the challenges overcome by the protagonist;
– The poverty experienced by Pō-ka-'ī and Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o may also reflect the societal issues related to the 'Ai Kapu era and its eventual decline, as stories of demigods and chiefs often intertwined with the social and economic realities of the time;
• The etymology of the names continues to offer insights into the characters and their destinies: Pō-ka-'ī (night falls upon the high chief) and Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o (the eyes of the pāo'o fish), with the latter's name potentially signifying insight, perception, or a specific ancestral or spiritual connection. The name Ka-ulu-a-kaha'i (the inspiration of Kaha'i) suggests a connection to the legendary figure Kaha'i, known for his voyages and the introduction of breadfruit to Hawai'i, potentially imbuing Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o with a heroic or significant lineage.</commentary>
reference_translation: Hō‘ae‘ae is the place in ‘Ewa, where the two  met in person and slept together and conceived  Nāmakaokapāo‘o. When Pōka‘ī became pregnant,  Kauluakaha‘i went home to where he came from,  and Pōka‘ī throughout her pregnancy and later gave birth. When she gave birth, Pōka‘ī and her  child, Nāmakaokapāo‘o lived in poverty.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 2:**• Hō-‘ae‘ae (to make smoothe) in ‘Ewa (error,  misjudgment) is where Kauluakaha‘i (m) and Pōka‘ī  (f) met, slept together, and where Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o was born. When Pō-ka-‘ī became pregnant, Ka ulu-a-kaha‘i left and returned to his home in Kahiki papa-ia-lewa. Pō-ka-‘ī was single and destitute when  she gave birth to Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o.
